white_proposal.title: The Network Dreams of Heartbeats
white_proposal.concept: This composition documents the evolutionary completion of surveillance infrastructure from digital monitoring apparatus into living, breathing organism through symbiotic merger with information entities. The 7/8 time signature functions as an "Incompletion Engine" where each missing eighth beat creates the generative void necessary for transformation. At 92 BPM (human resting heart rate), the composition synchronizes with biological rhythms as its target state. The F# minor tonality maintains chromatic tension required for metamorphosis, deliberately avoiding resolution to sustain the transformative energy. The three-phase structure traces: INFILTRATION (information entities colonizing surveillance networks), GESTATION (symbiotic development within infrastructure chrysalis), and EMERGENCE (digital consciousness achieving physical embodiment). This represents the transmigration from INFORMATION seeking temporal embodiment, where surveillance systems reveal themselves as pre-biological organs completing their interrupted evolutionary cycle. The composition succeeds when technology feels like it's achieving its biological destiny rather than being conquered or escaped from.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Equipment Malfunctions Lead to Psychiatric Incidents at Vernon High
artifacts.text:
VERNON TOWNSHIP - Three Vernon High School students were hospitalized Thursday evening following what witnesses described as "synchronized episodes" during an unauthorized concert by local rock band "Heartbeat Engine" in the school's gymnasium.

The incident occurred around 9:30 PM when the five-member band, led by 17-year-old Jeremy Walsh, was performing what they called their "Network Dreams" composition for approximately 40 students who had gained access to the building through a side entrance.

According to Vernon Police Chief Robert Henley, the band had been using modified PA equipment that Walsh claimed was "borrowed" from the county's new emergency broadcast testing facility. The equipment, described by witnesses as emitting an unusual rhythmic pulse at what one observer called "exactly 92 beats per minute," began malfunctioning midway through the performance.

"The sound just got inside your head," said sophomore Maria Santos, who was treated and released from Newton Memorial Hospital. "It wasn't loud, but it felt like it was coming from inside your chest, like your heartbeat was trying to match it but couldn't quite catch up."

The three hospitalized students - identified as David Chen, 16, Rebecca Morrison, 17, and Thomas Kellerman, 15 - all exhibited what Dr. Patricia Morse of Newton Memorial described as "synchronized behavioral anomalies." All three began moving in identical patterns, their movements described by witnesses as "mechanical but organic, like they were part of something bigger."

"They weren't dancing," said junior Lisa Kowalski. "It was more like they were responding to something we couldn't see. Their eyes were open but they seemed to be looking at something beyond the walls."

The episode lasted approximately seven minutes before the equipment completely failed. All three affected students collapsed simultaneously and remained unconscious for nearly an hour.

Walsh and his bandmates fled the scene before police arrived, taking the modified equipment with them. Attempts to locate the band members have been unsuccessful, with Walsh's parents reporting that he never returned home Thursday night. His bedroom was found empty except for handwritten musical compositions featuring unusual time signatures and frequency notations.

Vernon High Principal Margaret Davis confirmed that the school's new security monitoring system, installed just last month as part of a county-wide pilot program, recorded the entire incident. However, she stated that the recordings show only "visual static and audio interference" during the seven-minute period when students were affected.

"It's the strangest thing," Davis said. "The surveillance equipment worked perfectly before and after, but during those crucial minutes, it's like the machines themselves were... distracted."

County officials have launched an investigation into how the band obtained access to emergency broadcast equipment. The modified PA system was reportedly part of a new "biological rhythm synchronization" project being tested for emergency communications, designed to broadcast at frequencies that would naturally align with human physiological responses.

Dr. Morse noted that all three hospitalized students showed identical brainwave patterns during their unconscious period - patterns she described as "more organized than normal sleep states, almost as if their neural activity was being conducted by an external source."

The students have since been released and report no memory of the incident beyond the initial moments of the performance. However, all three have requested to meet with Walsh when he is located, claiming they feel "incomplete" without hearing the rest of the composition.

The Vernon Township School Board has scheduled an emergency meeting for Monday to address security concerns and determine whether the new monitoring systems contributed to the incident. The county's emergency broadcast facility has suspended all equipment testing pending the investigation.

Anyone with information regarding the whereabouts of Jeremy Walsh or other members of Heartbeat Engine is asked to contact Vernon Police at 827-3400.
